userStories.tip: Eat six small meals a day.

userStories.question: What’s your best coping strategy?

userStories.question: What’s your best coping strategy?

userStories.question: What’s your best coping strategy?

userStories.question: What tip would you give someone like me who was just diagnosed?
userStories.tip: Prescription drugs are not the answer, you must first remove all non-organic foods from your diet and then control the inflammation through probiotics/curcumin/boswellin

userStories.question: Besides medications, what else has worked for you?
userStories.tip: smoking

userStories.question: What tip would you give someone like me who was just diagnosed?
userStories.tip: Sulfazalasine

condition.description:
Ulcerative colitis (UC) is a disease that causes inflammation and sores, called ulcers, in the lining of the rectum and colon. It is one of a group of diseases called inflammatory bowel disease.

UC can happen at any age, but it usually starts between the ages of 15 and 30. It tends to run in families. The most common symptoms are pain in the abdomen and blood or pus in diarrhea. Other symptoms may include

  • Anemia
  • Severe tiredness
  • Weight loss
  • Loss of appetite
  • Bleeding from the rectum
  • Sores on the skin
  • Joint pain
  • Growth failure in children

About half of people with UC have mild symptoms.

Doctors use blood tests, stool tests, colonoscopy or sigmoidoscopy, and imaging tests to diagnose UC. Several types of drugs can help control it. Some people have long periods of remission, when they are free of symptoms. In severe cases, doctors must remove the colon.

NIH: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases
condition.name: Ulcerative colitis

carousel_items: Don't take Mesalamine if you're allergic to aspirin. Talk to your doctor or pharmacist about any drug allergies you have before starting Mesalamine.
Taking antacids with Mesalamine can make your inflammation worse. Talk to your doctor before you make any changes.
You can sunburn more easily when taking Mesalamine. Use sunscreen and protective clothing when you go outdoors.
Don't break, chew, or crush the tablets because they're coated and won't work as well.
The suppositories should be kept in for at least 1 to 3 hours to get the most benefit.

basics.benefits_moa: Mesalamine is an anti-inflammatory medication. Researchers don't know exactly how Mesalamine works in the colon, but it seems to lower the chemicals in the body that cause inflammation.
basics.bottom_line: Mesalamine is an effective first-line medicine for inflammatory bowel disease. There isn't a generic version and you'll have to take it multiple times a day.
downsides: No generic versions are available for the tablets, capsules, and suppositories (meaning it could be somewhat expensive).
Doesn't work well for severe colon inflammation.
You may need to take Mesalamine three or four times a day.
Not a good option if you have kidney disease.

downsides_processed.orig: No generic versions are available for the tablets, capsules, and suppositories (meaning it could be somewhat expensive).
Doesn't work well for severe colon inflammation.
You may need to take Mesalamine three or four times a day.
Not a good option if you have kidney disease.

upsides: Effective first-line medication for treating and lowering the symptoms of mild inflammatory bowel disease.
About half the people who have mild to moderate colon inflammation and take Mesalamine will see improvement.
Available in tablets, capsules, enemas, and suppositories.
Certain forms of Mesalamine can be used during pregnancy. Talk to your doctor if you're pregnant, or plan on becoming pregnant, and you want to take Mesalamine.

upsides_processed.orig: Effective first-line medication for treating and lowering the symptoms of mild inflammatory bowel disease.
About half the people who have mild to moderate colon inflammation and take Mesalamine will see improvement.
Available in tablets, capsules, enemas, and suppositories.
Certain forms of Mesalamine can be used during pregnancy. Talk to your doctor if you're pregnant, or plan on becoming pregnant, and you want to take Mesalamine.

userStories.tip: certain side effects only show up with max doses
These tend to be very large pills, and you take a lot of them daily. Setting a reminder for when to take them, or 2 with each meal helps. Definitely worth the trouble.
Time release tablets are big, but if you hold the a few seconds before trying to swallow, they dissolve into tasteless bits that are easy to swallow.

drugs.name: Asacol

Don't break, chew, or crush the tablets because they're coated and won't work as well.
The suppositories should be kept in for at least 1 to 3 hours to get the most benefit.

risks_warnings.title: Serious allergic reactions
risks_warnings.description: Rarely, Mesalamine can cause serious allergic reactions. These reactions can make it difficult to breathe or cause a severe rash that can be life-threatening. Stop taking Mesalamine and report any skin rash, fever, swelling, or trouble breathing to a doctor right away.

description_processed.orig: Rarely, Mesalamine can cause serious allergic reactions. These reactions can make it difficult to breathe or cause a severe rash that can be life-threatening. Stop taking Mesalamine and report any skin rash, fever, swelling, or trouble breathing to a doctor right away.

risks_warnings.title: Serious allergic reactions
risks_warnings.description: The formulation of Mesalamine known as Apriso contains phenylalanine, which can be harmful to people with phenylketonuria (PKU).

description_processed.orig: The formulation of Mesalamine known as Apriso contains phenylalanine, which can be harmful to people with phenylketonuria (PKU).

risks_warnings.title: Worsening kidney or liver function
risks_warnings.description: Mesalamine is broken down by the kidney and liver. If you have kidney or liver problems, talk to your doctor because you may need to take a different dose of the medication.

description_processed.orig: Mesalamine is broken down by the kidney and liver. If you have kidney or liver problems, talk to your doctor because you may need to take a different dose of the medication.

risks_warnings.title: Blood disorders
risks_warnings.description: Rarely, Mesalamine can lower white blood cell counts. White blood cells help your body fight infections. Tell your doctor if you have any infection symptoms (such as fever, sore throat, or mouth/throat swelling) that don't go away.

description_processed.orig: Rarely, Mesalamine can lower white blood cell counts. White blood cells help your body fight infections. Tell your doctor if you have any infection symptoms (such as fever, sore throat, or mouth/throat swelling) that don't go away.

risks_warnings.title: Liver toxicity
risks_warnings.description: Rarely, Mesalamine can cause liver injury, hepatitis, and liver failure. Let your doctor know and get medical attention if you notice yellowing skin or eyes.

description_processed.orig: Rarely, Mesalamine can cause liver injury, hepatitis, and liver failure. Let your doctor know and get medical attention if you notice yellowing skin or eyes.

risks_warnings.title: Worsening of colitis
risks_warnings.description: Mesalamine can cause colitis-like symptoms in some people when they start treatment. It’s noted with Asacol HD, but it can happen with other products. If you've started taking Mesalamine and have cramps, belly pain, bloody diarrhea, with or without fever, headache, weakness, rash, or eye inflammation, let your doctor know right away. You'll need to switch to another medicine. These symptoms should go away once Asacol HD tablets are stopped.
risk_factors: Taking Mesalamine at the start of treatment

description_processed.orig: Mesalamine can cause colitis-like symptoms in some people when they start treatment. It’s noted with Asacol HD, but it can happen with other products. If you've started taking Mesalamine and have cramps, belly pain, bloody diarrhea, with or without fever, headache, weakness, rash, or eye inflammation, let your doctor know right away. You'll need to switch to another medicine. These symptoms should go away once Asacol HD tablets are stopped.

carousel_items: Take Budesonide with meals to avoid upsetting your stomach.
Eating smaller, more frequent meals and drinking plenty of fluids is helpful while taking Budesonide.
Be sure to take Budesonide at the same time every day.
Don't eat or drink grapefruit while taking Budesonide since it can interfere with how the medication works.
Can't be used long-term.
Don't stop taking this medicine suddenly, but work with your doctor to slowly decrease the amount you take to avoid unwanted side effects.
Let your doctor know about any night sweating, unexplained fevers, or infections that won't get better.

basics.benefits_moa: Budesonide is a corticosteroid. It reduces the inflammation in your intestines by blocking the proteins that trigger inflammation.
basics.bottom_line: Budesonide helps treat Crohn’s disease and ulcerative colitis, but you can’t take it for long because of its serious side effects.
downsides: Many people decide to stop taking Budesonide because of its side effects.
Budesonide isn't recommended for long-term treatment.
You can’t drink alcohol while taking Budesonide.
Taking corticosteroids like Budesonide can make it hard for your body to fight infections.
Budesonide can pass into breast milk if you're nursing.

downsides_processed.orig: Many people decide to stop taking Budesonide because of its side effects.
Budesonide isn't recommended for long-term treatment.
You can’t drink alcohol while taking Budesonide.
Taking corticosteroids like Budesonide can make it hard for your body to fight infections.
Budesonide can pass into breast milk if you're nursing.

upsides: Budesonide works for 50-70% of people with mild to moderate Crohn’s disease.
Budesonide is preferred over Prednisone for treating people with Crohn’s disease.
Causes fewer side effects than other corticosteroids.
Low doses of Budesonide can be used for a few weeks or even a few months to achieve remission.

upsides_processed.orig: Budesonide works for 50-70% of people with mild to moderate Crohn’s disease.
Budesonide is preferred over Prednisone for treating people with Crohn’s disease.
Causes fewer side effects than other corticosteroids.
Low doses of Budesonide can be used for a few weeks or even a few months to achieve remission.

drugs.one_liner: Budesonide decreases inflammation from Crohn’s disease.

userStories.tip: started with 9 mg, then decreased to 6mg, and then 3 mg.
I take it in the morning w/a glass of water.  I used to take it at night but I suspected it caused some cramping in my feet.

drugs.name: Budesonide

carousel_items_processed.orig: Take Budesonide with meals to avoid upsetting your stomach.
Eating smaller, more frequent meals and drinking plenty of fluids is helpful while taking Budesonide.
Be sure to take Budesonide at the same time every day.
Don't eat or drink grapefruit while taking Budesonide since it can interfere with how the medication works.
Can't be used long-term.
Don't stop taking this medicine suddenly, but work with your doctor to slowly decrease the amount you take to avoid unwanted side effects.
Let your doctor know about any night sweating, unexplained fevers, or infections that won't get better.

risks_warnings.title: Adrenal suppression
risks_warnings.description: Adrenal suppression leading to adrenal crisis can occur when taking Budesonide. Symptoms include joint or muscle pain, extremely low energy, and depression. Changes in your Budesonide dose need to be done slowly over time. Talk to your doctor before you make any changes or stop your medication.

description_processed.orig: Adrenal suppression leading to adrenal crisis can occur when taking Budesonide. Symptoms include joint or muscle pain, extremely low energy, and depression. Changes in your Budesonide dose need to be done slowly over time. Talk to your doctor before you make any changes or stop your medication.

risks_warnings.title: Steroid use
risks_warnings.description: People who are switching from strong glucocorticosteroid treatment to weak glucocorticosteroid treatment like Budesonide can have symptoms of steroid withdrawal. These effects include adrenal suppression and adrenal crisis, which include symptoms of joint or muscle pain, extreme low energy, low blood pressure, fever, confusion, and depression.

description_processed.orig: People who are switching from strong glucocorticosteroid treatment to weak glucocorticosteroid treatment like Budesonide can have symptoms of steroid withdrawal. These effects include adrenal suppression and adrenal crisis, which include symptoms of joint or muscle pain, extreme low energy, low blood pressure, fever, confusion, and depression.

risks_warnings.title: Infections
risks_warnings.description: Patients taking immunosuppressive medications like Budesonide are more likely to develop infections. People who have not been vaccinated for diseases like chickenpox or measles should be careful to stay away from those infected.

description_processed.orig: Patients taking immunosuppressive medications like Budesonide are more likely to develop infections. People who have not been vaccinated for diseases like chickenpox or measles should be careful to stay away from those infected.

carousel_items: Humira is a medication that's injected under the skin (subcutaneous). Your doctor can give you your first dose, then let you self-inject it once so you learn how to do it correctly.
Humira lowers the your immune system's ability to fight infections, so it's important to let your doctor know if you come down with a fever, cough, or notice flu-like symptoms.
You'll need to have a TB test before you start using Humira.
Tell your doctor if you have an allergy to latex since the syringe needle cover has latex in it.
Don't inject Humira into skin that's red, bruised, or irritated. Rotate your injection areas to avoid skin reactions.
As with all injection medicines, store away from children and throw used syringes away in a protective container, and not in the trash.

basics.benefits_moa: Humira is a biologic response modifier. It works in the immune system to block a protein called TNF (tumor necrosis factor). Blocking TNF relieves symptoms and prevents disease progression.
basics.bottom_line: Humira is very effective at calming down your immune system, but it's expensive, you have to take into account the hassle of injections and traveling with the medication.
downsides: It's an injection.
It's expensive because there's no generic available yet.

Humira lowers your ability to fight infection and can cause serious life-threatening illness. The risk is greater if you take other drugs that lower your immune system, have an active infection, diabetes, or had tuberculosis (TB) in the past.

You're first dose of Humira will need to be given at your doctor's office. If you decide not to self-inject and don't have someone to do it for you, you'll need to continue to see your doctor for each dose.
You'll need to properly dispose of the needle, syringes, or Pen in a special (FDA-approved) sharps container.
Because it needs to be refrigerated until you use it, if you're traveling, you'll need to carry it in a cooler with an ice pack.

downsides_processed.orig: It's an injection.
It's expensive because there's no generic available yet.

Humira lowers your ability to fight infection and can cause serious life-threatening illness. The risk is greater if you take other drugs that lower your immune system, have an active infection, diabetes, or had tuberculosis (TB) in the past.

You're first dose of Humira will need to be given at your doctor's office. If you decide not to self-inject and don't have someone to do it for you, you'll need to continue to see your doctor for each dose.
You'll need to properly dispose of the needle, syringes, or Pen in a special (FDA-approved) sharps container.
Because it needs to be refrigerated until you use it, if you're traveling, you'll need to carry it in a cooler with an ice pack.

upsides: Treats certain types of arthritis and gastrointestinal conditions caused by an overactive immune system.
Most people feel it's worth the hassle.
Once you've learned the correct way to use Humira, you can inject the medicine yourself without going to your doctor's office.
It's available in a single-use pen (Humira Pen) that may be more convenient and easier for some people to use.
It's an alternative for people with Crohn's disease who stopped getting better on other TNF-blockers or had side effects that made them switch.

upsides_processed.orig: Treats certain types of arthritis and gastrointestinal conditions caused by an overactive immune system.
Most people feel it's worth the hassle.
Once you've learned the correct way to use Humira, you can inject the medicine yourself without going to your doctor's office.
It's available in a single-use pen (Humira Pen) that may be more convenient and easier for some people to use.
It's an alternative for people with Crohn's disease who stopped getting better on other TNF-blockers or had side effects that made them switch.

userStories.tip: Works great. No more flares
Keep to your dosing schedule - keep dates when they're due on your calendar or diary.  Try to do it at a weekend when you aren't rushing or likely to forget!
When you take the Humira out of the fridge, hold it under your arm for 10 minutes or so to let it war to room temperature-it stings a lot less.
take the injection out of the fridge and let it come to room temp before injecting!
No more loose bowl movements, signs of blood, or lack of energy. Humira works great with my other medications to control UC.

Travelling can be huge pain with this refridgeerator medication. There are 30 hour chill containers out there. One piece of advice that really help me is if you can find ice. Do to the nearest fast food place and bring a ziploc bag
Makes my life so much better because I don't have flair ups. I don't have side effects or get sick easily either.
I find the prefilled syringes to be significantly less painful than the pen. Also, I only inject my thighs.

drugs.name: Humira

carousel_items_processed.orig: Humira is a medication that's injected under the skin (subcutaneous). Your doctor can give you your first dose, then let you self-inject it once so you learn how to do it correctly.
Humira lowers the your immune system's ability to fight infections, so it's important to let your doctor know if you come down with a fever, cough, or notice flu-like symptoms.
You'll need to have a TB test before you start using Humira.
Tell your doctor if you have an allergy to latex since the syringe needle cover has latex in it.
Don't inject Humira into skin that's red, bruised, or irritated. Rotate your injection areas to avoid skin reactions.
As with all injection medicines, store away from children and throw used syringes away in a protective container, and not in the trash.

risks_warnings.title: Serious allergic reactions
risks_warnings.description: Humira has been reported to cause hypersensitivity reactions (severe rash, trouble breathing) and angioedema (life-threatening condition with swelling with or without hives). If you notice these symptoms after your dose or days later, call your doctor and get medical care right away.

description_processed.orig: Humira has been reported to cause hypersensitivity reactions (severe rash, trouble breathing) and angioedema (life-threatening condition with swelling with or without hives). If you notice these symptoms after your dose or days later, call your doctor and get medical care right away.

risks_warnings.title: Heart problems
risks_warnings.description: Humira may not be the best choice if you have advanced heart failure with symptoms. If you have mild heart failure and your condition hasn't improved on any other medicine talk to your doctor to see if Humira is right for you. You may have to take lower doses and have heart testing before  and during treatment.

description_processed.orig: Humira may not be the best choice if you have advanced heart failure with symptoms. If you have mild heart failure and your condition hasn't improved on any other medicine talk to your doctor to see if Humira is right for you. You may have to take lower doses and have heart testing before  and during treatment.

risks_warnings.title: Serious infections
risks_warnings.description: Humira can increase your risk of serious or life-threatening bacterial, fungal and viral infections. In some cases infections can be reactivated from an inactive virus in your body like tuberculosis (TB) or hepatitis B virus (HBV). You may need to take medicine for TB before you can begin taking Humira. If you develop symptoms of cough, fever, chills, muscle aches, feel very tired, or you notice dark urine, yellowing of skin/eyes, appetite/weight loss, vomiting, change in stool color, stomach discomfort, and skin rash,  tell your doctor and get medical care right away.

description_processed.orig: Humira can increase your risk of serious or life-threatening bacterial, fungal and viral infections. In some cases infections can be reactivated from an inactive virus in your body like tuberculosis (TB) or hepatitis B virus (HBV). You may need to take medicine for TB before you can begin taking Humira. If you develop symptoms of cough, fever, chills, muscle aches, feel very tired, or you notice dark urine, yellowing of skin/eyes, appetite/weight loss, vomiting, change in stool color, stomach discomfort, and skin rash,  tell your doctor and get medical care right away.

risks_warnings.title: Malignancy
risks_warnings.description: Based on how Humira works, it may lower the body's defenses against malignancies and control how they develop and grow. There appears to be a higher risk of lymphoma, some other cancers, and non-melanoma skin cancer (NMSC) in people who take Humira.

description_processed.orig: Based on how Humira works, it may lower the body's defenses against malignancies and control how they develop and grow. There appears to be a higher risk of lymphoma, some other cancers, and non-melanoma skin cancer (NMSC) in people who take Humira.

risks_warnings.title: Nervous system effects
risks_warnings.description: Although rare, Humira can cause nervous system conditions such as multiple sclerosis (MS) and Guillain Barre syndrome. If you currently have a nervous system condition, your doctor will watch you closely while your taking Humira since it can make them worse. Let your doctor know right away if you notice numbness or tingling, weakness in arms or legs, vision problems or dizziness.

description_processed.orig: Although rare, Humira can cause nervous system conditions such as multiple sclerosis (MS) and Guillain Barre syndrome. If you currently have a nervous system condition, your doctor will watch you closely while your taking Humira since it can make them worse. Let your doctor know right away if you notice numbness or tingling, weakness in arms or legs, vision problems or dizziness.

risks_warnings.title: Blood problems
risks_warnings.description: Humira can affect blood cells that help you fight infection and stop bleeding. Let your doctor know if you develop a fever that doesn't go away, or you easily bruise, or bleed. You may need to stop taking this medicine.

description_processed.orig: Humira can affect blood cells that help you fight infection and stop bleeding. Let your doctor know if you develop a fever that doesn't go away, or you easily bruise, or bleed. You may need to stop taking this medicine.

carousel_items: Remicade is a medication that's given as an infusion at your doctor's office or clinic.
It's very important to read the patient Medication Guide when you first start using Remicade.
It's possible to get an allergic reaction to Remicade either immediately during the treatment or a several days after stopping it. Your doctor can give you medicines that'll lower this risk.
You'll need to have a TB test before you start taking Remicade and periodically during treatment.

Remicade lowers your immune system's ability to fight infections, so it's important to let your doctor know if you notice a fever, cough, or flu-like symptoms. Children seem to get more infections than adults, so keep a close eye on them.

If you have a young child, let their doctor know if you were on Remicade while pregnant or nursing. It can increase their risk of infections for several months after your last dose and can delay their vaccine schedule.

basics.benefits_moa: Remicade is a biologic response modifier. It works in the immune system to block a protein called TNF (tumor necrosis factor). Blocking TNF relieves symptoms and prevents disease progression.
basics.bottom_line: Remicade is very effective at calming down your immune system, but you have to get each dose at your doctor's office and watch out for serious side effects.
downsides: You have to get every dose through an IV infusion at your doctor's office.
It's expensive because there's no generic available yet.

Remicade has a higher risk of serious infusion-related side effects during or after it's given since it's injected right into your veins. Your doctor can prescribe medication before your dose that may lower this risk.

Remicade lowers your ability to fight infection and can cause serious life-threatening illness. The risk is greater if you take other drugs that lower your immune system, have an active infection, diabetes, or had tuberculosis (TB) in the past.
Not the best choice if you have heart failure.

Talk to your baby's doctor if you're pregnant or breast-feeding. When women in a study took Remicade, the medicine was found in their breast milk 2 to 3 days after each dose, and in the baby's blood 6 months after they were born.

downsides_processed.orig: You have to get every dose through an IV infusion at your doctor's office.
It's expensive because there's no generic available yet.

Remicade has a higher risk of serious infusion-related side effects during or after it's given since it's injected right into your veins. Your doctor can prescribe medication before your dose that may lower this risk.

Remicade lowers your ability to fight infection and can cause serious life-threatening illness. The risk is greater if you take other drugs that lower your immune system, have an active infection, diabetes, or had tuberculosis (TB) in the past.
Not the best choice if you have heart failure.

Talk to your baby's doctor if you're pregnant or breast-feeding. When women in a study took Remicade, the medicine was found in their breast milk 2 to 3 days after each dose, and in the baby's blood 6 months after they were born.

upsides: Treats certain types of arthritis and gastrointestinal conditions caused by an overactive immune system.
Remicade has almost two decades of clinical trial data and real-life experience with millions of people who have used it.
Initial dosing to introduce Remicade to your body might be a hassle, but then you only need to take it every 6-8 weeks depending on your condition.

upsides_processed.orig: Treats certain types of arthritis and gastrointestinal conditions caused by an overactive immune system.
Remicade has almost two decades of clinical trial data and real-life experience with millions of people who have used it.
Initial dosing to introduce Remicade to your body might be a hassle, but then you only need to take it every 6-8 weeks depending on your condition.

userStories.tip: Remicade changed my life. Before I started it, I was in constant pain and had a difficult time getting out of a chair or turning over in bed. Now I have only minor pain and live a full and happy life.
Have gotten severe psoriasis from the medication.
Make sure to get lots of rest for the rest of the day. Don't go on a plane within a day or two or you will get sick.
userStories.identifier: early 30s single with 70 hour work week

userStories.tip: I have been in remission since my first dose!

drugs.name: Remicade

carousel_items_processed.orig: Remicade is a medication that's given as an infusion at your doctor's office or clinic.
It's very important to read the patient Medication Guide when you first start using Remicade.
It's possible to get an allergic reaction to Remicade either immediately during the treatment or a several days after stopping it. Your doctor can give you medicines that'll lower this risk.
You'll need to have a TB test before you start taking Remicade and periodically during treatment.

Remicade lowers your immune system's ability to fight infections, so it's important to let your doctor know if you notice a fever, cough, or flu-like symptoms. Children seem to get more infections than adults, so keep a close eye on them.

If you have a young child, let their doctor know if you were on Remicade while pregnant or nursing. It can increase their risk of infections for several months after your last dose and can delay their vaccine schedule.

risks_warnings.title: Serious allergic reactions
risks_warnings.description: Remicade has been reported to cause hypersensitivity reactions (severe rash, trouble breathing) and angioedema (life-threatening condition with swelling with or without hives). If you notice these symptoms after your dose or days later, call your doctor and get medical care right away.

description_processed.orig: Remicade has been reported to cause hypersensitivity reactions (severe rash, trouble breathing) and angioedema (life-threatening condition with swelling with or without hives). If you notice these symptoms after your dose or days later, call your doctor and get medical care right away.

risks_warnings.title: Heart problems
risks_warnings.description: Remicade may not be the best choice if you have advanced heart failure with symptoms. If you have mild heart failure and your condition hasn't improved on any other medicine talk to your doctor to see if Remicade is right for you. You may have to take lower doses and have heart testing before  and during treatment.

description_processed.orig: Remicade may not be the best choice if you have advanced heart failure with symptoms. If you have mild heart failure and your condition hasn't improved on any other medicine talk to your doctor to see if Remicade is right for you. You may have to take lower doses and have heart testing before  and during treatment.

risks_warnings.title: Serious infections
risks_warnings.description: Remicade can increase your risk of serious or life-threatening bacterial, fungal and viral infections. In some cases infections can be reactivated from an inactive virus in your body like tuberculosis (TB) or hepatitis B virus (HBV). You may need to take medicine for TB before you can begin taking Remicade. If you develop symptoms of cough, fever, chills, muscle aches, feel very tired, or you notice dark urine, yellowing of skin/eyes, appetite/weight loss, vomiting, change in stool color, stomach discomfort, and skin rash,  tell your doctor and get medical care right away.

description_processed.orig: Remicade can increase your risk of serious or life-threatening bacterial, fungal and viral infections. In some cases infections can be reactivated from an inactive virus in your body like tuberculosis (TB) or hepatitis B virus (HBV). You may need to take medicine for TB before you can begin taking Remicade. If you develop symptoms of cough, fever, chills, muscle aches, feel very tired, or you notice dark urine, yellowing of skin/eyes, appetite/weight loss, vomiting, change in stool color, stomach discomfort, and skin rash,  tell your doctor and get medical care right away.

risks_warnings.title: Malignancy
risks_warnings.description: Based on how Remicade works, it may lower the body's defenses against malignancies and control how they develop and grow. There appears to be a higher risk of lymphoma, some other cancers, and non-melanoma skin cancer (NMSC) in people who take Remicade.

description_processed.orig: Based on how Remicade works, it may lower the body's defenses against malignancies and control how they develop and grow. There appears to be a higher risk of lymphoma, some other cancers, and non-melanoma skin cancer (NMSC) in people who take Remicade.

risks_warnings.title: Nervous system effects
risks_warnings.description: Although rare, Remicade can cause nervous system conditions such as multiple sclerosis (MS) and Guillain Barre syndrome. If you currently have a nervous system condition, your doctor will watch you closely while you're taking Remicade since it can make them worse. Let your doctor know right away if you notice numbness or tingling, weakness in arms or legs, vision problems or dizziness.

description_processed.orig: Although rare, Remicade can cause nervous system conditions such as multiple sclerosis (MS) and Guillain Barre syndrome. If you currently have a nervous system condition, your doctor will watch you closely while you're taking Remicade since it can make them worse. Let your doctor know right away if you notice numbness or tingling, weakness in arms or legs, vision problems or dizziness.

risks_warnings.title: Blood problems
risks_warnings.description: Remicade can affect blood cells that help you fight infection and stop bleeding. Let your doctor know if you develop a fever that doesn't go away, or you easily bruise, or bleed. You may need to stop taking this medicine.

description_processed.orig: Remicade can affect blood cells that help you fight infection and stop bleeding. Let your doctor know if you develop a fever that doesn't go away, or you easily bruise, or bleed. You may need to stop taking this medicine.

risks_warnings.title: Liver injury
risks_warnings.description: Although rare, Remicade can cause serious liver injury. You'll need to have your liver enzymes tested regularly. If liver enzymes are significantly elevated and you have appetite/weight loss, stomach discomfort, vomiting, and notice dark urine, yellowing of skin/eyes, change in stool color, and skin rash you should stop treatment with Remicade until you can be completely assessed,

description_processed.orig: Although rare, Remicade can cause serious liver injury. You'll need to have your liver enzymes tested regularly. If liver enzymes are significantly elevated and you have appetite/weight loss, stomach discomfort, vomiting, and notice dark urine, yellowing of skin/eyes, change in stool color, and skin rash you should stop treatment with Remicade until you can be completely assessed,

points.name: Infusion reaction

points.notes: generally occurred within 2 weeks after repeat infusion
points.name: Delayed hypersensitivity reaction

carousel_items: The dose and duration on how long you need the medicine depends on your condition and response.
Take it exactly as your doctor prescribed.
Take with food to decrease stomach upset.
Can cause trouble sleeping. Take in the morning or 2-3 hours before bed if more than one dose is needed.
Can cause changes in mood, blood pressure, blood sugar, and water retention.
You should check your blood pressure and blood sugar when taking this medicine if you already have high blood pressure or diabetes.
A taper is often needed to stop the medicine, especially if you've been on it for more than 1 week.

basics.benefits_moa: Medrol is a corticosteroid that's similar to what your body naturally makes. It reduces swelling and other immune responses that can cause you pain, discomfort, or harm.
basics.bottom_line: Medrol is corticosteroid available in many forms (oral, injectable) that's great for controlling the unwanted symptoms from your immune responses and will make you feel better. There are lots of side effects but most of are tolerable or can be managed.
downsides: Lots of side effects, especially with long term use.
Short-term use can cause mood changes, trouble sleeping and increase in blood pressure, blood sugar, and possible water retention.
Long-term use can cause problems with skin, bone, eye health and put you at a higher risk for infections.
People with certain conditions will have to pay extra attention to their symptoms or may have to adjust the dose of other medicines when taking Medrol.
When using corticosteroids for more than 1 week, you will need to work with a doctor to get off the medicine slowly.

downsides_processed.orig: Lots of side effects, especially with long term use.
Short-term use can cause mood changes, trouble sleeping and increase in blood pressure, blood sugar, and possible water retention.
Long-term use can cause problems with skin, bone, eye health and put you at a higher risk for infections.
People with certain conditions will have to pay extra attention to their symptoms or may have to adjust the dose of other medicines when taking Medrol.
When using corticosteroids for more than 1 week, you will need to work with a doctor to get off the medicine slowly.

upsides: Steroid magic, can help you feel better, have more energy and get more appetite.
Useful in controlling immune responses that are causing you discomfort, and works quickly to relieve symptoms like swelling, rash, asthma attacks, gout attacks.
Useful in suppressing the immune system from causing your body harm, like many autoimmune related conditions.
Available in many different forms, including injection, that will expose the rest of your body less of the medicine.

drugs.name: Medrol

carousel_items_processed.orig: The dose and duration on how long you need the medicine depends on your condition and response.
Take it exactly as your doctor prescribed.
Take with food to decrease stomach upset.
Can cause trouble sleeping. Take in the morning or 2-3 hours before bed if more than one dose is needed.
Can cause changes in mood, blood pressure, blood sugar, and water retention.
You should check your blood pressure and blood sugar when taking this medicine if you already have high blood pressure or diabetes.
A taper is often needed to stop the medicine, especially if you've been on it for more than 1 week.

risks_warnings.title: Adrenal suppression (HPA axis suppression)
risks_warnings.description: Adrenal suppression leading to adrenal crisis can occur if you lower your dose or stop taking Medrol too quickly. Symptoms include joint or muscle pain, extreme low energy and depression. Changes in your Medrol dose need to be done slowly over time. Talk to your doctor before you make any changes or stop the medication.
risk_factors: Lowering dose or stopping too quickly especially after long-term treatment
Stress such as trauma, surgery or infection

description_processed.orig: Adrenal suppression leading to adrenal crisis can occur if you lower your dose or stop taking Medrol too quickly. Symptoms include joint or muscle pain, extreme low energy and depression. Changes in your Medrol dose need to be done slowly over time. Talk to your doctor before you make any changes or stop the medication.

risks_warnings.title: Kaposi's sarcoma
risks_warnings.description: It’s rare, but taking Medrol for a long period of time, can increase your risk of Kaposi’s sarcoma, a type of cancer that can affect both the skin and internal organs. Your doctor will monitor you closely while you're taking Medrol and if this develops, will work with you to slowly lower your dose and stop the medication.

description_processed.orig: It’s rare, but taking Medrol for a long period of time, can increase your risk of Kaposi’s sarcoma, a type of cancer that can affect both the skin and internal organs. Your doctor will monitor you closely while you're taking Medrol and if this develops, will work with you to slowly lower your dose and stop the medication.

risks_warnings.title: Eye problems
risks_warnings.description: Medrol may cause cataracts or glaucoma, increased eye pressure and possibly eye nerve damage. You may also be more at risk for certain eye infections. Don't take if you have herpes simplex of the eye.  Let your doctor know if you have blurry vision, eye pain or any vision changes.

description_processed.orig: Medrol may cause cataracts or glaucoma, increased eye pressure and possibly eye nerve damage. You may also be more at risk for certain eye infections. Don't take if you have herpes simplex of the eye.  Let your doctor know if you have blurry vision, eye pain or any vision changes.

risks_warnings.title: Psychiatric changes
risks_warnings.description: Like most corticosteroid medicines, Medrol may cause changes in your mood or behavior. Tell your doctor right away if you become depressed, have mood swings, trouble sleeping, irritability or anxiety, hyperactivity,  delusions or hallucinations while taking this medicine. If you need to make any changes or slowly taper your dose, talk to your doctor first.

description_processed.orig: Like most corticosteroid medicines, Medrol may cause changes in your mood or behavior. Tell your doctor right away if you become depressed, have mood swings, trouble sleeping, irritability or anxiety, hyperactivity,  delusions or hallucinations while taking this medicine. If you need to make any changes or slowly taper your dose, talk to your doctor first.

risks_warnings.title: Bone effects
risks_warnings.description: Medrol can thin the bones and decrease the growth rate in children. Talk to the doctor about medicine choices that won't negatively affect growth. Use the lowest possible dose to treat the condition and have the doctor monitor your child’s height during treatment.

description_processed.orig: Medrol can thin the bones and decrease the growth rate in children. Talk to the doctor about medicine choices that won't negatively affect growth. Use the lowest possible dose to treat the condition and have the doctor monitor your child’s height during treatment.

risks_warnings.title: Harm to fetus
risks_warnings.description: Taking Medrol if your pregnant or breast-feeding can harm your unborn baby. If you need to take a systemic corticosteroid during pregnancy, the lowest dose that will help treat your condition should be used for the shortest time, especially during your first trimester. Your doctor will let you know if there are other medicine choices that are safer (e.g. inhaled steroids for asthma). If you're taking Medrol to treat an autoimmune condition like rheumatoid arthritis or for antirejection treatment after a transplant, there are disease registries that you'll need to contact so make sure you talk to your doctor.

description_processed.orig: Taking Medrol if your pregnant or breast-feeding can harm your unborn baby. If you need to take a systemic corticosteroid during pregnancy, the lowest dose that will help treat your condition should be used for the shortest time, especially during your first trimester. Your doctor will let you know if there are other medicine choices that are safer (e.g. inhaled steroids for asthma). If you're taking Medrol to treat an autoimmune condition like rheumatoid arthritis or for antirejection treatment after a transplant, there are disease registries that you'll need to contact so make sure you talk to your doctor.

risks_warnings.title: Stomach and intestinal problems
risks_warnings.description: Taking Medrol increases the risk of injury to the lining of your stomach and intestine including irritation, tears/holes and ulcers. You should avoid alcohol/alcoholic beverages because it can worsen stomach irritation. Tell your doctor or get medical care right away if you have stomach pain, notice blood or dark colored stools when you go to the bathroom.
risk_factors: Active or history of stomach or duodenal ulcers
Taking Medrol with other medicine that can cause stomach problems

description_processed.orig: Taking Medrol increases the risk of injury to the lining of your stomach and intestine including irritation, tears/holes and ulcers. You should avoid alcohol/alcoholic beverages because it can worsen stomach irritation. Tell your doctor or get medical care right away if you have stomach pain, notice blood or dark colored stools when you go to the bathroom.

risks_warnings.title: Increased risk for infections
risks_warnings.description: If you take Medrol for a long time it can increase your risk of all types of infections, make it hard to tell if you have one, take longer to fight and be more serious. Be careful not to be in contact with anyone who has the chicken pox or measles. If you had tuberculosis (TB) in the past your doctor will need to monitor you while taking Medrol. You may need to take medicine to prevent getting it or treat it if your TB comes back. Talk to your doctor before taking Medrol if you haven't had vaccinations against certain viral diseases, are under stress or regularly around sick people.
risk_factors: Contact with people who have viral illness
History of bacterial or viral conditions

description_processed.orig: If you take Medrol for a long time it can increase your risk of all types of infections, make it hard to tell if you have one, take longer to fight and be more serious. Be careful not to be in contact with anyone who has the chicken pox or measles. If you had tuberculosis (TB) in the past your doctor will need to monitor you while taking Medrol. You may need to take medicine to prevent getting it or treat it if your TB comes back. Talk to your doctor before taking Medrol if you haven't had vaccinations against certain viral diseases, are under stress or regularly around sick people.

points.name: Congestive heart failure in susceptible patients
Aseptic necrosis of femoral and humeral heads
Peptic ulcer with possible perforation and hemorrhage
Increases ALT, SGPT, AST, SGOT, and alkaline phosphatase
May suppress reactions to skin tests
Increased requirements of insulin or oral hypoglycemic agents in diabetics

carousel_items: Don't use if you are allergic to sulfa drugs or aspirin.
Swallow tablets whole, and take after a meal with a full glass of water.
Drink at least six glasses of water daily while on this.
Continue to take Sulfasalazine even once you feel better.
Read the information that come with your medication in the drugstore since there are many conditions you should be aware of before taking Sulfasalazine.
Can cause an orange color in your urine or skin.

basics.benefits_moa: Sulfasalazine is an anti-inflammatory drug that reduces inflammation and pain. It treats inflammatory bowel diseases and rheumatoid arthritis.
basics.bottom_line: Sulfasalazine is used for moderate to severe inflammatory bowel conditions, and with other meds for treating rheumatoid arthritis.
downsides: You need to have blood tests every 3 months when taking Sulfasalazine.
Sulfasalazine isn't a good option if you have kidney or liver disease.
Can't take Sulfasalazine if you are allergic to aspirin or sulfa medications.
Sulfasalazine shouldn't be used if you are breastfeeding.

downsides_processed.orig: You need to have blood tests every 3 months when taking Sulfasalazine.
Sulfasalazine isn't a good option if you have kidney or liver disease.
Can't take Sulfasalazine if you are allergic to aspirin or sulfa medications.
Sulfasalazine shouldn't be used if you are breastfeeding.

upsides: When taken consistently, Sulfasalazine can control your symptoms of ulcerative colitis and other bowel diseases.
Sulfasalazine is usually used in combination with other medications to control rheumatoid arthritis.

upsides_processed.orig: When taken consistently, Sulfasalazine can control your symptoms of ulcerative colitis and other bowel diseases.
Sulfasalazine is usually used in combination with other medications to control rheumatoid arthritis.

userStories.tip: Makes things Orange. I have even been told my skin looks Orange.

It's great medicine. However after 5 years, i was doing really fine. i discontinued sulfasalazine without my doctors consent. After a year or so, the inflammatory symptoms reoccur. Hence don't discontinue it, it's life saving medicine.

drugs.name: Sulfasalazine

off-label_indications.indication: Gastrointestinal tract inflammation caused by radiation

carousel_items_processed.orig: Don't use if you are allergic to sulfa drugs or aspirin.
Swallow tablets whole, and take after a meal with a full glass of water.
Drink at least six glasses of water daily while on this.
Continue to take Sulfasalazine even once you feel better.
Read the information that come with your medication in the drugstore since there are many conditions you should be aware of before taking Sulfasalazine.
Can cause an orange color in your urine or skin.

risks_warnings.title: Kidney damage
risks_warnings.description: Complete blood counts should be done before starting Sulfasalazine and every other week during the first three months of treatment. Since kidney damage can occur, you'll need a urinalysis and an assessment of your kidney function periodically during treatment.

description_processed.orig: Complete blood counts should be done before starting Sulfasalazine and every other week during the first three months of treatment. Since kidney damage can occur, you'll need a urinalysis and an assessment of your kidney function periodically during treatment.

risks_warnings.title: Serious skin reactions
risks_warnings.description: Severe and possibly fatal reactions (e.g. Stevens-Johnson syndrome, toxic epidermal necrolysis) can happen anytime and as early as the first day while taking Sulfasalazine. Tell your doctor or get medical help right away if you notice sores or fluid-filled blisters on your skin, lips, or inside your mouth. You won't be able to re-start Sulfasalazine after this reaction.

description_processed.orig: Severe and possibly fatal reactions (e.g. Stevens-Johnson syndrome, toxic epidermal necrolysis) can happen anytime and as early as the first day while taking Sulfasalazine. Tell your doctor or get medical help right away if you notice sores or fluid-filled blisters on your skin, lips, or inside your mouth. You won't be able to re-start Sulfasalazine after this reaction.

risks_warnings.title: Serious allergic reactions
risks_warnings.description: Severe hypersensitivity reactions can include internal organ involvement, such as hepatitis (liver), nephritis (kidney), myocarditis (heart), blood abnormalities, or pneumonitis (lungs).

description_processed.orig: Severe hypersensitivity reactions can include internal organ involvement, such as hepatitis (liver), nephritis (kidney), myocarditis (heart), blood abnormalities, or pneumonitis (lungs).

risks_warnings.title: Drug interactions
risks_warnings.description: When taking Sulfasalazine with either folic acid and digoxin, it causes both other medications to not be absorbed by your body as well.

description_processed.orig: When taking Sulfasalazine with either folic acid and digoxin, it causes both other medications to not be absorbed by your body as well.
